title: Dow rises 300 points as stocks bounce back from losing week
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA rose 326 points, or 1%, to 33,226.

* The S&P 500 SPX was up 57 points, or 1.4%, at 4,166.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP advanced 215 points, or 1.8%, to trade at 12,227.

Stocks fell sharply Friday, dragging major indexes to weekly losses. The Dow declined 0.9% last week, while the S&P 500 dropped 1.2% and the Nasdaq Composite shed 1%.

What's driving markets

Analysts are assessing whether stocks have dropped enough given the Fed's desire to stamp out inflation by lifting interest rates. Key inflation data is set for release on Friday.

"Market pricing of Fed rate hikes has cooled recently on market expectations that inflation is bound to come down. This spurred a rebound in equities from 2022 lows and stopped the U.S. dollar rally in its tracks. In other words, markets have moved as if inflation is yesterday's story. We disagree," wrote strategists at BlackRock Investment Institute, in a note.

"Sure, core inflation is bound to come down from 40-year highs. But we see it as persistent and running above the Fed's 2% target for years to come," they wrote. "We see short -term risk of a snap back in the market's rate expectations as data show the persistence of inflation — and as the Fed keeps talking tough on inflation."

That's also a setup for continued market volatility, they said. Other analysts agreed.

"When the economy looks strong — market worries shift to inflation and the risk of higher interest rates. When the data are weaker — the opposite happens. The result? Volatility," said analysts at RockCreek, a Washington, D.C. investment firm.

Markets also were paying attention to signs the White House is loosening its stance on tariffs. U.S. Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said household goods and bicycles "may make sense" as products to ease levies. Solar companies including SunRun Inc. RUN rose after The Wall Street Journal reported there won't be any new tariffs on solar imports for two years.

Companies in focus

* Shares of Twitter Inc. TWTR fell 3.3% after Tesla Inc. TSLA CEO Elon Musk disclosed that he reiterated his request for information as he evaluates the number of spam and fake accounts on the social media company's platform. Musk said he reserves the right to terminate his planned acquisition of Twitter if he chooses.

* The largest U.S. company by market capitalization, Apple Inc. AAPL, will be in the spotlight as it holds a developers conference in which it's expected to unveil new products. Apple shares rose 1.9%.

* JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU boosted its offer for Spirit Airlines Inc. SAVE on Monday in the latest move in the three-way battle for the discount airline. Spirit has been trying to fight off the JetBlue bid so it can go ahead with an earlier plan to merge with Frontier Group Holdings Inc. ULCC and has said it fears a JetBlue deal would be blocked by regulators. Spirit shares rose 5.6%, while JetBlue shares were up 2.2% and Frontier shares gained 5.5%.

* Amazon.com Inc.'s AMZN 20-for-1 stock split has taken effect. The stock closed Friday at a pre-split adjusted $2,447, and was trading up 4.8% above $128. The last time the stock traded below the four-digit level pre-split was October 2017. The split is Amazon's first in 23 years.

* Shares of UnderArmour Inc. UA UAA were up 1.1% after S&P Dow Jones Indices said it was booting the athletic apparel and gear maker from the S&P 500. The company and IPG Photonics Corp. IPGP are moving down from the large-cap benchmark to the S&P MidCap 400, S&P Dow Jones Indices said late Friday. Shares of Keurig Dr Pepper Inc. KDP rallied 4.6% and ON Semiconductor Corp. ON climbed 5.8%, as the companies will replace Under Armour and IPG Photonics in the S&P 500.

What other assets are doing

* The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y rose around 5 basis points to 3.01%, the first time its traded above the 3% threshold on an intraday basis since May 18. Yields and debt prices move opposite each other.

* The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, was flat.

* Oil futures gave up early gains to trade near unchanged, with the U.S. benchmark CL.1 down 0.1% at $118.75 a barrel after ending Friday at a nearly three-month high.

* Gold futures GC00 were fractionally lower just below $1,850 an ounce.

* Bitcoin BTCUSD rose 5.2% to trade near $31,500.

* The Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP rose 1.2%, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX advanced 1.4%.

* The Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP ended 1.3% higher on Monday, while the Hang Seng Index HK:HSI advanced 2.7% in Hong Kong and Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIK gained 0.6%.
